external_links.text: Regulatory requirements and guidance for use of nutrition and health-related statements and claims on supplemented foods
external_links.context: For more information on health claims in SFs, refer to Regulatory requirements and guidance for use of nutrition and health-related statements and claims on supplemented foods in the Health Canada Guidance document: Supplemented Foods Regulations .

external_links.text: Is my product a supplemented food (SF)?
external_links.section: Steps for determining the type of health claim
external_links.context: Note : the food may be a supplemented food. For more information, refer to Is my product a supplemented food (SF)? in the Health Canada Guidance document: Supplemented Foods Regulations .

external_links.section: Steps for determining the type of health claim
external_links.context: Use Drugs versus foods to verify if the claim refers to a Schedule A.1 disease or is a drug claim. If yes, see Drug representations and pre-market approval to learn about their specific requirements such as obtaining a pre-market approval in certain cases. Disease risk reduction claims or therapeutic claims must be based on sound scientific evidence that has established a relationship between certain elements of healthy diets and the reduction of risk of developing certain diseases.

external_links.text: Natural health product regulation in Canada
external_links.context: For more information on the above criteria or on NHPs, please consult Health Canada's webpage Natural health product regulation in Canada .

Health Canada is in the process of working with manufacturers to safely transition food products previously marketed as NHPs to the food regulatory framework. This has been facilitated through the issuance of Temporary Marketing Authorization Letters (TMAL) by the Food Directorate. For a complete list of TMALs, see the List of foods that have received Temporary Marketing Authorization Letters .

external_links.text: List of foods that have received Temporary Marketing Authorization Letters
external_links.context: Health Canada is in the process of working with manufacturers to safely transition food products previously marketed as NHPs to the food regulatory framework. This has been facilitated through the issuance of Temporary Marketing Authorization Letters (TMAL) by the Food Directorate. For a complete list of TMALs, see the List of foods that have received Temporary Marketing Authorization Letters .
For more information on authorized NHPs, please consult Health Canada's Licensed Natural Health Products Database and Natural Health Products Ingredients Database .
For more information on authorized NHPs, please consult Health Canada's Licensed Natural Health Products Database and Natural Health Products Ingredients Database .

Furthermore, section 3 of the FDA prohibits the sale of a food that is labelled or advertised to the general public as a treatment, preventative or cure for any of the diseases referred to in Schedule A.1 .

Section 3 of the Food and Drugs Act (FDA) prohibits the sale of a food that is labelled or advertised to the general public as a treatment, preventative or cure for any of the diseases referred to in Schedule A.1 , unless exempted within the Food and Drug Regulations (FDR).

When a health claim makes reference to a Schedule A.1 disease, a pre-market assessment of the claim by Health Canada's Food Directorate is mandatory and an amendment to the FDR is required before the use of the claim is permitted.

external_links.text: Guidance Document for Preparing a Submission for Food Health Claims
external_links.context: For information on obtaining a pre-market approval, visit Health Canada's Guidance Document for Preparing a Submission for Food Health Claims .

Drug claims about diseases or health conditions not listed in Schedule A.1 are subject to the same level of standards of evidence as claims about Schedule A.1 diseases or conditions; however, pre-market assessment of the claim is voluntary.

Health claims that have been voluntarily submitted and accepted by Health Canada's Food Directorate will be added to the list of accepted claims and may be used on all food products meeting the conditions of use for that claim. A summary of health claim assessments is published on their website for claims that have already been reviewed.

external_links.text: Guidance Document for Preparing a Submission for Food Health Claims
external_links.context: For information on submitting a pre-market assessment, visit Health Canada's Guidance Document for Preparing a Submission for Food Health Claims .

external_links.section: Acceptable disease risk reduction claims and therapeutic claims
external_links.context: For claims listed on Health Canada's website, see the Health claim assessment for the claim made.

external_links.text: Nutrient and health-related claims and the front-of-package (FOP) nutrition symbol
external_links.section: Acceptable disease risk reduction claims and therapeutic claims
external_links.context: For more information refer to Nutrient and health-related claims and the front-of-package (FOP) nutrition symbol of the FOP nutrition symbol labelling guide for industry.

external_links.text: Restrictions on size of acceptable claims for supplemented foods with a supplemented food caution identifier
external_links.section: Acceptable disease risk reduction claims and therapeutic claims
external_links.context: For more information refer to Restrictions on size of acceptable claims for supplemented foods with a supplemented food caution identifier in the Health Canada Guidance document: Supplemented Foods Regulations

external_links.section: Acceptable disease risk reduction claims and therapeutic claims
external_links.context: When a disease risk reduction or therapeutic claim appears on the label of a supplemented food that has an ADS of less than 100 cm 2 , the food loses its small package exemption and is required to carry a Supplemented Food Facts table [B.029.018(2)(b)(iii), FDR]. For more information, refer to small package exemption in the Health Canada Guidance document: Supplemented Foods Regulations .

external_links.text: Regulatory requirements and guidance for use of nutrition and health-related statements and claims on supplemented foods
external_links.section: Acceptable disease risk reduction claims and therapeutic claims
external_links.context: There are specific restrictions to be aware of when using disease risk reduction claims and therapeutic claims on certain supplemented foods. Refer to Regulatory requirements and guidance for use of nutrition and health-related statements and claims on supplemented foods of Health Canada's Guidance document: Supplemented Foods Regulations for more information.

external_links.text: Types of health claims and their regulatory requirements
external_links.context: Requirements for function claims for other ingredients, including non-nutritive supplemental ingredients, can be found in Types of health claims and their regulatory requirements and Health claims general guidance in the Health Canada Guidance document: Supplemented Foods Regulations .

Requirements for function claims for other ingredients, including non-nutritive supplemental ingredients, can be found in Types of health claims and their regulatory requirements and Health claims general guidance in the Health Canada Guidance document: Supplemented Foods Regulations .

When a function claim appears on the label of a supplemented food that has an available display surface of less than 100 cm 2 , the food is required to carry a Supplemented Food Facts table [B.029.018(2)(b)(iii), FDR]. For more information, refer to Small package exemption in the Health Canada Guidance document: Supplemented Foods Regulations .

external_links.text: Nutrient and health-related claims and the front-of-package (FOP) nutrition symbol
external_links.context: For more information, refer to Nutrient and health-related claims and the front-of-package (FOP) nutrition symbol of the Front-of-package nutrition symbol labelling guide for industry.

external_links.text: Restrictions on size of acceptable claims for supplemented foods with a supplemented food caution identifier
external_links.context: For more information, refer to Restrictions on size of acceptable claims for supplemented foods with a supplemented food caution identifier in the Health Canada Guidance document: Supplemented Foods Regulations .

Companies wanting to make function claims must have scientific evidence to validate the claim prior to its use on food labels or in advertisements. This evidence may be used by the CFIA, in collaboration with Health Canada, to evaluate product compliance with the Food and Drugs Act and Regulations . Consequently, manufacturers and importers are encouraged to contact the Food Directorate of Health Canada for advice regarding the acceptability of function claims on food products prior to their use. Claims reviewed and found to be acceptable will be added to the Table of acceptable food or food constituent function claims .

external_links.text: Health and Medicine Division of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine
external_links.context: Nutrients include carbohydrate, protein, fat, fatty acids, sugars and the vitamins and minerals listed in Part D, FDR. Additionally, substances recognized as nutrients by the Health and Medicine Division of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine , Washington, D.C. are considered nutrients. Other food components, such as lycopene, lutein, anthocyanins and other compounds found in foods are not considered nutrients for labelling purposes.

When a nutrient function claim is made on supplemented foods in small packages with an ADS of less than 100 cm 2 , they lose their exemption and are required to declare a SFFt [B.29.018(2), FDR]. For more information, refer to Small package exemption in the Health Canada Guidance document: Supplemented Foods Regulations .

external_links.text: Determination of the protein rating using the Protein Digestibility Corrected Amino Acid Score (PDCAAS)
external_links.context: 20 or more, obtained using the method FO-1, Determination of Protein Rating, October 15, 1981; or 8 or more, obtained using the method Determination of the protein rating using the Protein Digestibility Corrected Amino Acid Score (PDCAAS) , published by the Government of Canada on its website, as amended from time to time [Item 44, Table of chemical, physical and nutritional characteristics of food ]. Refer to item 8 of table B. Protein Related Statements and Claims of the Table of Permitted Nutrient Content Statements and Claims.

external_links.text: Table of chemical, physical and nutritional characteristics of food
external_links.context: 20 or more, obtained using the method FO-1, Determination of Protein Rating, October 15, 1981; or 8 or more, obtained using the method Determination of the protein rating using the Protein Digestibility Corrected Amino Acid Score (PDCAAS) , published by the Government of Canada on its website, as amended from time to time [Item 44, Table of chemical, physical and nutritional characteristics of food ]. Refer to item 8 of table B. Protein Related Statements and Claims of the Table of Permitted Nutrient Content Statements and Claims.

external_links.text: B. Protein Related Statements and Claims
external_links.context: 20 or more, obtained using the method FO-1, Determination of Protein Rating, October 15, 1981; or 8 or more, obtained using the method Determination of the protein rating using the Protein Digestibility Corrected Amino Acid Score (PDCAAS) , published by the Government of Canada on its website, as amended from time to time [Item 44, Table of chemical, physical and nutritional characteristics of food ]. Refer to item 8 of table B. Protein Related Statements and Claims of the Table of Permitted Nutrient Content Statements and Claims.

external_links.text: Amino acid claims for supplemented foods
external_links.context: Note that representations about amino acids used as supplemental ingredients are acceptable for SFs that do not meet the requirement for a "source of protein" claim [B.01.305(2), FDR]. Refer to Amino acid claims for supplemented foods in the Health Canada Guidance document: Supplemented Foods Regulations .

When nutrient function claims are made for vitamin and mineral nutrients, the vitamin or mineral nutrient must be listed in column 1 of Part 2 of the Table of Daily Values . The food must contain a minimum of 5% of the daily value for the vitamin or mineral stated in the claim (meaning being at least a dietary source of the nutrient), as per the Table of Daily Values . The quantity of the vitamin or mineral nutrient that is the subject of the claim must appear in the Nutrition Facts table in absolute amount and percent daily value (% DV), if not already required.

When nutrient function claims are made for vitamin and mineral nutrients, the vitamin or mineral nutrient must be listed in column 1 of Part 2 of the Table of Daily Values . The food must contain a minimum of 5% of the daily value for the vitamin or mineral stated in the claim (meaning being at least a dietary source of the nutrient), as per the Table of Daily Values . The quantity of the vitamin or mineral nutrient that is the subject of the claim must appear in the Nutrition Facts table in absolute amount and percent daily value (% DV), if not already required.

external_links.text: Health claims about microorganisms and use of the term "probiotic"
external_links.context: Health Canada's document on Health claims about microorganisms and use of the term "probiotic" provides more details on the conditions under which health claims about probiotics are considered acceptable.

Non-strain-specific claims are general statements about the nature of probiotics. A closed list of accepted non-strain-specific probiotic claims is available in the Table of health claims about live microorganisms – Part A: Non-strain-specific health claims . Manufacturer can use these claims without the need to conduct a detailed review of the scientific basis. Strain-specific claims are claims about the beneficial health effect of specific strains of probiotics. At the present time, no strain-specific claims have been accepted by Health Canada. As these claims are reviewed and accepted, Health Canada will create a list of acceptable strain-specific claims that will be available in the Table of health claims about live microorganisms – Part B: Strain-specific health claims .

Non-strain-specific claims are general statements about the nature of probiotics. A closed list of accepted non-strain-specific probiotic claims is available in the Table of health claims about live microorganisms – Part A: Non-strain-specific health claims . Manufacturer can use these claims without the need to conduct a detailed review of the scientific basis. Strain-specific claims are claims about the beneficial health effect of specific strains of probiotics. At the present time, no strain-specific claims have been accepted by Health Canada. As these claims are reviewed and accepted, Health Canada will create a list of acceptable strain-specific claims that will be available in the Table of health claims about live microorganisms – Part B: Strain-specific health claims .

external_links.text: Health claims about microorganisms and use of the term "probiotic"
external_links.context: The following is key information from Health Canada's document on Health claims about microorganisms and use of the term "probiotic" . Consult the document for more details.

Only a few non-strain-specific claims about the nature of probiotics are accepted on food labels. Examples include "probiotic that naturally forms part of the gut flora" and "provides live microorganisms that contribute to healthy gut flora". These statements or claims can be made about a food that contains at least one of the eligible species at the minimum levels (1.0 x 10 9 cfu per serving of stated size) as specified in the Table of health claims about live microorganisms – Part A: Non-strain-specific health claims . Documentation supporting the functionality aspects of the food (such as the identity, quantity, safety, stability, concentration and viability of the live microorganism strain(s)) should be retained and maintained. Manufacturers and importers should have this information ready to disclose upon request by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency. The manufacturer or importer must follow all requirements applicable to the sale of food, including those related to the use and labelling of ingredients used in novel technology in the delivery of a viable microorganism for food application.

external_links.text: Guidance Documents for Preparing Health Claim Submissions
external_links.context: For substantiation of the strain-specific health claim, petitioners should follow the guidelines outlined in the Guidance Documents for Preparing Health Claim Submissions . At the present time, no strain-specific claims have been accepted by Health Canada. See Table of health claims about live microorganisms – Part B: Strain-specific health claims .

For substantiation of the strain-specific health claim, petitioners should follow the guidelines outlined in the Guidance Documents for Preparing Health Claim Submissions . At the present time, no strain-specific claims have been accepted by Health Canada. See Table of health claims about live microorganisms – Part B: Strain-specific health claims .

A probiotic claim should be accompanied by the Latin name of the microorganism (that is to say, genus and species), along with the strain identity of the microorganism, using acceptable nomenclature (see the Table of health claims about live microorganisms – Part A: Non-strain-specific health claims for nomenclature of selected bacterial species).

external_links.text: Health claims about microorganisms and the use of the term "probiotic"
external_links.context: For consistency, it is recommended that the strain be identified by using the number assigned by an internationally recognized culture repository (for example, American Type Culture Collection; ATCC 2008). For more information, consult the References section of Heath Canada's document on Health claims about microorganisms and the use of the term "probiotic" .
For labelling and advertising of health claims on foods containing Lactobacillus , refer to Nomenclature changes to Lactobacillus .

The word "healthy" refers to the healthy eating patterns recommended by Canada's food guide . The use of the word "healthy" on a food that does not meet the recommendations of Canada's food guide could be misleading.

Similarly, the use of the word "nutritious" or "healthy" on small packages of supplemented foods that are normally exempt from declaring a Supplemented Food Facts table cause a loss of exemption [B.29.018(2)(b)(ii)]. The use of these terms in reference to bulk foods does not trigger any additional information to be declared.
As obesity is included in Schedule A.1 of the Food and Drugs Act , foods may not be advertised as a treatment, preventative or cure for this condition.

The principal display panel of the label of the food and any advertisements for the food carries the statement, "As part of healthy eating, this food may assist in maintaining a healthy body weight because it is... (for example, "lower in energy than...", "low in fat", "portion controlled", etc.). The label displays the Nutrition Facts table (see Nutrition labelling for the general requirements for declaring the Nutrition Facts table). Labels or advertisements may make reference to statements from Canada's food guide. For more information on the conditions of use of content from the food guide, refer to the Government of Canada's website on Terms and conditions . The label, packaging or advertisements do not give the impression that the food is for use in a weight-reduction diet. Requirements regarding foods represented for use in a weight-reduction diet are set out in Division 24 of the FDR and summarized in Foods for special dietary use . Brand and trade names traditionally considered as claims for weight reduction are qualified with the statement "for weight maintenance" next to the brand or trade name on the principal display panel.

external_links.section: Health claims for children under 4 years of age
external_links.context: Disease risk reduction claims are not permitted on foods that are intended solely to be consumed by children less than 4 years of age, such as infant cereal and pureed fruits and vegetables [B.01.601(1)(c)(i), FDR]. Likewise, the claims set out in Health Canada's Health Claim Assessments that are not in the FDR are only for use on food for adults.
Consult Health Canada's Natural Health Product (NHP) Compounding Policy to obtain the lists of included and excluded natural health product substances [ Schedule 1 and 2 ].
Consult Health Canada's Natural Health Product (NHP) Compounding Policy to obtain the lists of included and excluded natural health product substances [ Schedule 1 and 2 ].
Consult Appendix A-Statutory Provisions of Health Canada's Guidance Document: Schedule A.1 and Section 3 to the Food and Drugs Act . to obtain the list of diseases.

external_links.text: Health claims about microorganisms and use of the term "probiotic"
external_links.context: To obtain the list of the references related to probiotic claims, refer to the References section of Health Canada's page on Health claims about microorganisms and use of the term "probiotic" .
